STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 28, 2024
JILL SCHREUDER
CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN - BENTON HA
185 E. MAIN STREET ST.102,
BENTON HARBOR, MI, 49022-4432
RE: License#: CB110403982
Dear JILL SCHREUDER:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 8/19/2024-8/27/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written
corrective action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date
of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB110403982
Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities West Michigan
Licensee Designee: JILL SCHREUDER
Chief Administrator: JILL SCHREUDER
Name of Agency: CATHOLIC CHARITIES WEST MICHIGAN -
BENTON HA
Agency Address: 185 E. MAIN STREET ST.102
BENTON HARBOR, MI 49022-4432
Agency Telephone #: 2695931000
Original Issuance Date: 04/21/2020
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 8/19/2024
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 1 1
Homes pending licensure 0 0
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 1 1
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 2 2

in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 33 6
Children discharged from care during this period 41 4

since the last inspection 0 0
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 2 2

Open child adoption cases

More than a year 2 2

Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
• (2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may
occur:
• (d) Three references obtained from
persons who are unrelated to the staff
person.
One of Fourteen employee files reviewed contained 2 of the 3 references
required prior to hire.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (a) Approval from the certifying agency
authorizing the placement of a child in the
home.

Two of Two borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation of the
approval from the lending agency in the record prior to the placement of the
youth.
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (b) Verification that the foster parent is
willing to accept the foster child.
Two of Two borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent was willing to accept the placement in the record prior to the placement of
the youth.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (f) Documentation that the foster parent
has received orientation to the policies of
the borrowing agency.
Two of Two borrowed bed files reviewed did not contain documentation the foster
parent received orientation entered in the record prior to the placement of the
youth.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22

CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home
• (1) Before placing a child in a foster home
certified by another agency the borrowing
agency shall have a record containing all the
following:
• (g) A copy of the foster parent /agency
agreement signed by the foster parent
and the borrowing agency.
Two of Two borrowed bed files reviewed contained foster parent agency
agreements signed after the placement of the youth.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
• (1) An agency's medical and dental care policy
must, include all the following:
• (c) A physical examination for each child
as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
• (ii) A physical examination every
14 months.
One of Six open files of youth in foster care placement did not contain
documentation of a timely periodic medical exam.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (3) When case responsibility changes from 1
child placing agency to another child placing
agency, a modified service plan must be
completed within 30 calendar days of the
change in agency responsibility if no other plan
is done within 30 days. The plan must address
why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing
service plans.

Two of Six open files of youth in foster care placement did not contain
modified/completed service plans including the required content following a case
transfer.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (6) Service plans must be signed by the social
services worker and the social services
supervisor.
Three of Eight open files of youth in care (6 FC, 2 IL) did not contain signatures of
the worker and/or supervisor on all service plans.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 9/13/23, CAP Approval 9/27/23
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement
• (2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in
independent living.
Two of Two open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
signed program statements regarding the agency's IL program.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures
• (3) An agency shall provide a youth in
independent living with a copy of the agency's
policies and procedures required by this rule.
Two of Two open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
signed policies and procedures regarding the agency's IL program.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
• (2) All the following must be in the case record
before a youth is placed in independent living:

• (c) That the youth's social service worker
has personally observed and determined
that the living situation is safe, and that
the youth has a bed and has access to
cooking and bathing facilities.
One of Two open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
documentation of the worker assessing the youth's home for safety or
appropriateness. Case contacts indicated no worker has been inside the home for
the three months the case has been assigned to the agency.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
• (2) An agency shall provide the following
minimum supervision:
• (a) Face-to-face contact between the
social service worker and the youth in
independent living at least once each
month at a youth's place of residence.
Two of Two open files of youth in independent living placement contained
documentation that all face to face visits with the youth in the youth's home were
not completed as required. One file documented that none of the face to face
visits with the youth occured in the youth's home. The other file indicated one
monthly visit was missed due to the youth cancelling the visit after the case
transferred and the previous worker had not conducted a visit.
CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision
• (2) An agency shall provide the following
minimum supervision:
• (b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the
youth is complying with the terms of the
required by R 400.12510, continues to
reside in a safe and acceptable
environment, and is managing
expenditures.
Two of Two open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
documentation of monthly contract compliance assessment.

CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (1) There must be a mutual agreement between
the youth and the agency specifying all the
following:
• (a) The responsibilities of the agency and
the youth.
Two of Two open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain a
mutual agreement specifying the responsibilities of the agency and youth.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated by
the youth and the social service worker. The
agreement must be reviewed with the youth at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy
provided to the youth.
Two of Two open files of youth in independent living placement did not contain
initial or updated signed and dated independent living agreements.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
CPA Rule 400.12604 Orientation
• (1) An agency shall provide an orientation for
prospective applicants for adoption before an
adoptive application is provided.
One of One adoptive family file reviewed contained documentation that the
application was provided and signed prior to the orientation.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
• (1) An agency social service worker shall
complete a written adoptive evaluation within 90
days of the family signing an adoption
application and prior to approving a family for
adoption.

Two of Two adoptive family files reviewed contained documentation that the
adoptive family assessment was not completed within 90 days of the signed
application.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22 , CAP Approval 10/6/22
Interim Inspection Report 9/13/23, CAP Approval 9/27/23
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case
Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement
or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for
every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business
days of the FTM.

Four of Eight open files of youth in care (6 FC, 2 IL) did not contain all required
FTMs and/or FTM paperwork.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
Interim Inspection Report 9/13/23, CAP Approval 9/27/23
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face
contacts per month with each child in the first two
months following an initial placement or a placement
change.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
The contact standards detailed in this section are
required anytime a child is placed with their parent or
legal guardian.
Residential or Institutional Setting
When a child is placed in a residential or institutional
setting, the caseworker must have contact with the
case manager/therapist assigned to the child, as
described in this section.
MiSACWIS Documentation
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting,
or safe sleep verification for infants, occurred for each
child participant in the Participant screen within the
Social Work Contact section of MiSACWIS.
Two of Eight open files of youth in care (6 FC, 2 IL) did not meet all foster home
visit requirements. One file contained case contacts that did not include
documentation of quality visits, including efforts to meet with the youth alone and
observing sleeping arrangements. One file contained documentation that the
caregiver was not present for one monthly home visit.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 9/13/23, CAP Approval 9/27/23

FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND
SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker
• Supervisor
• Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
• Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
• Youth ages 14 and older.
• Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must
check yes or no for the following when signing the
treatment plan:
• I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
• I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
• I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to
sign the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify,
and document actions needed to secure the parent’s
and/or youth’s participation in service planning and
compliance with the treatment plan.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Four of Eight open files of youth in care (6 FC, 2 IL) did not contain all required
PATP signatures obtained timely.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/13/22, CAP Approval 10/6/22
Interim Inspection Report 9/13/23, CAP Approval 9/27/23

FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following: • Foster care
provider. • Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care. The actual
date the medical passport is provided must be
documented in the electronic case management
record. Note: Foster care provider includes foster
homes, shelter, adult foster home, fictive kin, relative
placements, detention, and residential facilities.
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect
the child's current and complete health information.
Each caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the
medical passport verifying that they have sought and
obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents if the child is a temporary
court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification. Non-offending parent,
subsequent medical passports are not required after
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. Note: Non-offending parent with custody of
the child is not considered a foster parent placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to whom
the child is newly referred to and accepted for
treatment or services prior to or at the first scheduled
appointment while the foster care case is open,
regardless of placement. Subsequent medical
passports are not required.
• Older youth/young adults: Upon initial independent
living placement (youth aged 16 and over). Upon

exiting the foster care system (young adults aged 18
and older)
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed
parties is documented in the electronic case
management record by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
Two of Eight open files of youth in care (6 FC, 2 IL) did not contain all medical
passports updated as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 9/13/23, CAP Approval 9/27/23
PA 116 -722.120(1)(c) Investigation, Inspection, and Examination of
conditions, books, records, and reports
The department may investigate, inspect, and examine
conditions of a childcare organization and may
investigate and examine books and records of the
licensee. The licensee shall cooperate with the
department’s investigation, inspection, and examination
by doing all of the following:
(c) Providing accurate and truthful information to the
department, and encouraging witnesses, such as staff
and household members, to provide accurate and
truthful information to the department.
Three of Eight open files of youth in care (6 FC, 2 IL) contained document
signatures that were backdated, altered, or otherwise falsified. The documents
involved were case service plans & PATPs. The documents that were falsified
were all uploaded the weeks prior to the audit, despite having signature dates
throughout the period under review. Some of the documents were signed by a
worker and/or supervisor other than those currently assigned using a former
worker or supervisor's name and a backdated signature.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Timely uploading is crucial to maintaining a complete and accurate record
eliminating the need to track down documents for the inspection.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Borrowed Bed rule requires that everything must be documented and in the
record prior to the placement (unless the placement is after hours in which case
everything can be obtained/documented within 3 days) subsections (a) through
(f) must all be documented within the case record either in social work contacts
or through document uploads prior to placement. The foster parent agency
agreement must be signed and uploaded prior to placement, unless subsection
(2) applies.
• One file reviewed of a case open for nearly one month had minimal case
contacts and documents entered. This case should be reviewed by supervision
to ensure adequate engagement efforts are being made.
• When a worker transports youth to a medical or dental appointment, they should
bring the required forms for completion to upload after the appointment.
• Only the person who wrote/reviewed a service plan and/or PATP should be
signing the document as the signature serves as documentation they
wrote/approved the content. If someone involved in writing or reviewing the
report must sign the date after the fact (i.e. forgot to do it at the time of approval)
they must date it the actual date they signed it, not backdate to the date they
should have signed it. No one should sign/enter anyone else’s name. Signing
someone else’s name and/or backdating anything would be considered
falsification. The only circumstance someone would type in someone else’s
name and initial it, would be if that person gave them permission to do so
because they couldn’t, for some reason. In that case, you would want to
document why that was done and how/when permission was granted. This is
why it is important to obtain signatures and be sure they are entered into the
record timely.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The one
CAP submitted by the agency was in response to the interim licensing insepction
report dated 9/13/2023 and was approved on 9/27/2023. That CAP addressed 12
violations (7 licensing and 5 contract/policy.) Six of those violations were rectified
(performance evals, replacement notifications, periodic dental, notification of
rights, monthly visits with youth, and child adoption assessment visits) as
evidenced by there being no repeat citations in those areas and six of the
violations (service plan signatures, adoptive family assessment timeframes, FTMs,
case contacts, PATP signatures, and medical passport updates) were not rectified
as evidences by those areas remaining in violation during this year's review. Of
those 6 repeated violations, 3 (adoptive family assessment timeframes, FTMs, and
PATP signatures) have been repeated violations over the past 3 years and will
require asssessment of why previous CAPs were unsuccessful.
There has been an increase in number of citations from 11 in 2022 (6 rule & 5
policy,) 12 in 2023 (7 rule, 5 policy), to 22 (17 rule, 4 policy, & 1 PA 116 ) in 2024.
The increase can partially be attributed to an increase in number of cases being
managed by the agency, a significant number of new staff, and the additional of IL
cases which have not previously been reviewed at the agency. Additionally, the
majority of cases being managed by the agency were recently transferred from
other agencies. The most concerning citation is the PA 116 citation related to
providing accurate and truthful information during inspection. This citation was
exclusive to service plan signatures in 3 files reviewed and was performed by staff
who recently came to the agency. This was immediately addressed by agency
leadership with those staff to ensure they understand the agency expectations.
The increase in citations, the number of repeat citations, as well as the severity of
the violations need to be assessed by agency leadership to develop an
appropriate and effective corrective action plan.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator Assessment was received and reviewed. The chief
administrator identified several areas of the previously submitted CAP that were
implemented and successful; however, a complete staff turnover, including the
addition of multiple workers with no previous experience has resulted in licensing
rule and contract/policy violations while the staff learn the job requirements and
expectations.
Financial Overview
Reviewed the agency budget as well as the independent auditor's report on
financial statements, statements of financial position, statement of activities,
statement of functional expenses, statements of cash flows, and notes to financial

statements were reviewed. While there was a decrease in revenue due to low
cases during a portion of 2023, the agency has since accepted several cases. No
concerns were identified.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviewed who are new to the agency reported the onboarding process
has been smooth and they are receiving adequate training, support, and
supervision. The staff interviewed who have been at the agency for more than a
year reported no concerns despite several staffing changes at the agency.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency office is in a building with other non-profit agency offices. The office is
secured through locked doors. The staff work area with space and equipment to
provide for foster care, licensing, and adoption service delivery is located behind a
second locked door, which is also where the files are securely stored. Physical
CHRI is stored in a locked cabinet next to a cross shredder within the Program
Manager's office.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
No Safety Concerns Identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
August 28, 2024
_____________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 29, 2024
_____________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
